node.text:
What's the most exciting technology shaping design these days?  It's ... biology! Turns out, there's a biological replacement for cotton, plastic and almost everything else, according to Suzanne Lee, designer, engineer and founder of @biofabricate consultancy. Using these would cut down on waste and reduce the drain on precious resources like water and energy. Added bonus (and it's a big one!): Biofabricated  materials are often stronger and stand up better to daily wear and tear than conventionally manufactured goods. As Lee declares, "We need a material revolution and we need it now." Watch her full talk here to learn how we could “grow” textiles, leather substitutes and potentially even houses — all from living organisms: http://t.ted.com/B50Zf0w

[Made in collaboration with @ATTN]

node.title: Growing Clothes, Bricks and More from Living Organisms

node.text: Sadly, too many students today don't realize that they're genuinely creative and talented. And it's because too many schools don't value — and sometimes actively  discourage! — the very things they're good at. In one of his TED Talks, the late Sir Ken Robinson explains how traditional education is actually preventing kids from developing and showcasing their natural abilities — and that we must allow them to experiment, take chances and occasionally fail. "If you're not prepared to be wrong," he says, "you'll never come up with anything original." Watch the full version to see why it's the most-viewed TED Talk ever: http://t.ted.com/2orrPtm

node.text: Ever wonder why your voice always sounds so terrible — or just, unrecognizable — on recordings? There's actually a scientific reason way you *think* you sound is so different from how you actually sound. In her TED Talk, voice expert Rébecca Kleinberger explains the infuriating phenomenon: "Your outward voice travels through the air while your inward voice travels through your bones," she says. "Because of this, your inward voice is going to sound in a lower register and also more musically harmonical than your outward voice." Watch her fascinating full talk on the science of your many voices — and how you hear them — here: http://t.ted.com/QZb58m6

node.title: Why You Hate the Sound of Your Own Voice

node.text: Feel like you’re going a million miles a minute most days? Us too! As technology keeps our world moving faster and faster, there is so much value in slowing down, says writer @Jacqueline_Woodson. That’s why she recommends you make time to “savor” your books. Reading this way can help you dive deep into the many layers of a story, honor the author’s work and truly understand each book’s lasting power. "We read to get lost, to forget the hard times we're living in," she says. "And we read to remember those who came before us, who lived through something harder." Watch her full talk on the power of reading slowly here: http://t.ted.com/7S8xv4m

node.text: Bhakti Sharma has swum in all 5 oceans, crossed the English Channel (known as the Mount Everest of swimming), and even set a world record in the freezing Southern Ocean that encircles Antarctica! In her TED Talk, she shares how such feats of open water swimming taught her how to be resilient. "When you find yourself alone in an ocean with your thoughts, the dangers that you face are not just external -- like whales, sharks, jellyfish," she says. "The more dangerous demons you face are the fear and negativity inside you that tell you 'You're not good enough.'" Watch her full talk to get her advice for finding motivation and being the best possible version of yourself: http://t.ted.com/daaLz2q

node.title: What Open Water Swimming Taught Me About Resilience

node.text: Climate change has been on everyone's minds lately. From the alarming occurrence of wildfires, floods and extreme weather events to the UN’s newest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report, it’s easy to feel scared, angry or hopeless. Turns out, it's not just our communities and physical well-being that are being harmed by climate change — it's our mental heath too, according to science writer Britt Wray (@gen_dread). “We cannot afford to treat the psychological impacts of climate change as some afterthought,” says Wray. “Mental health needs to be an integral part of any climate change survival strategy.” To learn more about how a warming world affects us — and what we can do about it — watch her full talk: http://t.ted.com/Gj9DE7y

node.title: Talking About Climate Change Means Talking About Mental Health

node.text: Can a game of peekaboo really change the world? Yes! Because kids’ brains develop faster in their first 5 years of life than in any other period, what parents and caregivers do — or don't do — in those years matters. A lot. And interactive games like peekaboo can help build core skills like memory, trust, empathy and imagination. But don’t just take our word for it! In this TED Talk, created in partnership with @minderoofoundation, 7-year-old Molly Wright walks through the research-backed ways that you can support the babies, toddlers and young children in your life thrive by 5. To hear more from Molly about why playing peekaboo is a must for all kids, watch her adorable full talk here: http://t.ted.com/0YbX8vr

node.title: A Talk that All Parents Need to Hear

node.text: Being in a loving, committed partnership is not a guarantee for good sex, says relationship therapist Esther Perel (@estherperelofficial). In her TED Talk, she explains how the ways that you show love to a partner (reliability, security, protection) can sometimes be in direct conflict with the ingredients that spark desire (surprise, power, mischief). "Why is the forbidden so erotic?" she asks. "What is it about transgression that makes desire so potent?" Watch her full talk to learn the secrets of couples who manage to maintain a strong sexual connection: http://t.ted.com/bVejKYd

node.title: The Secret to Desire in Relationships

node.text: What is the real reason that athletes across many sports keep setting new records? Are humans simply getting taller, faster, stronger and just ... better? Or could there be another cause? In his TED Talk, David Epstein (@davidepstein) reveals that there are a number of factors behind the broken records. For one, "a form of artificial selection" has taken place within individual sports, drawing people with very specific body types. Here's an example: After the NBA signed an agreement in 1983 that made basketball a much more lucrative sport, the number of NBA players who were at least 7 feet tall doubled! Watch his fascinating full talk here: http://t.ted.com/kdKa26a

node.title: Are Humans Getting Faster and Stronger?

node.text: We need to call a time-out on "win-at-all-costs" culture and define what success really means, says Valorie Kondos Field, the former UCLA women's gymnastics coach. "As parents, as coaches, as leaders, we can no longer lead from a place where winning is our only metric of success, where our ego sits center stage," she explains in her TED Talk. "Real success is developing champions in life for our world — win or lose." Watch her brutally honest talk on the human consequences of our culture of winning here: http://t.ted.com/QCpwy7i

node.title: Why We Need to Redefine Success

node.text: Deep beneath the ocean's surface — 650 to 3,000 feet below! — lies a dark, frigid and rarely explored area called the “twilight zone”. It gets almost no sunlight and hovers around 40°F. 🥶 And the bottom dwellers that reside there? Just as otherworldly as the name of their home implies — they have bioluminescent bodies, tentacles galore, singular ways of moving and mating, and all kinds of other unique characteristics! But these critters are not just cool looking, they also play an important role in keeping CO2 out of our atmosphere. “The animals feed near the surface," says ocean scientist Heidi Sosik of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (@whoi.ocean). "They bring carbon in their food into the deep waters, where some of that carbon can stay behind and remain isolated from the atmosphere for hundreds or even thousands of years.” Watch her full talk on how she's leading the effort to protect and explore these uncharted waters and their inhabitants — and preserve their ability to protect the Earth’s climate: http://t.ted.com/rVrptCo

node.title: The Incredible Sea Creatures of the Twilight Zone

node.text: Do you struggle with feelings of shame? You’re not alone! So many of us experience shame in our everyday lives, according to vulnerability researcher and author @BreneBrown. "If you put shame in a petri dish, it needs three things to grow exponentially —secrecy, silence and judgment,” she explains. So how can you overcome these feelings? The key is empathy, says Brown. "If you put the same amount [of shame] in a petri dish and douse it with empathy, it can't survive." To learn about the amazing things that can happen when you confront your shame head on, watch Brené Brown’s full TED Talk here: http://t.ted.com/TSln3xB

node.title: We Need to Talk About Shame

node.text:
What's the most exciting technology shaping design these days?  It's ... biology! Turns out, there's a biological replacement for cotton, plastic and almost everything else, according to Suzanne Lee, designer, engineer and founder of @biofabricate consultancy. Using these would cut down on waste and reduce the drain on precious resources like water and energy. Added bonus (and it's a big one!): Biofabricated  materials are often stronger and stand up better to daily wear and tear than conventionally manufactured goods. As Lee declares, "We need a material revolution and we need it now." Watch her full talk here to learn how we could “grow” textiles, leather substitutes and potentially even houses — all from living organisms: http://t.ted.com/B50Zf0w

[Made in collaboration with @ATTN]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'TE TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "What makes a successful person is not being fearless, but pushing through the things that scare you the most." KESHA MUSICIAN, ACTRESS & ACTIVIST TED'.

node.text: Being scared is OK; it’s what you do next that really matters. Before her performance for TEDWomen in 2020, Grammy-nominated pop star Kesha (@iiswhoiis) delivered an inspiring message on the power of perseverance. Start your Monday off right, and visit the link in our bio to watch her earthshaking rendition of “Shadow” now! #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"When the world asks us big questions that require big answers, we have two options: 1. To feel so overwhelmed or unqualified, we do nothing. 2. To start with one small act and qualify ourselves." CLEO WADE ARTIST, poeT & AUTHOR TED'.

node.text: Are you feeling overwhelmed by the world’s many problems right now? First, know that it’s 100% OK to feel this way. Second, try this advice from artist, poet and author @CleoWade: Turn your feelings into action. "The world will say to you, 'What are you doing to do?'" she says. "Do not be afraid to say, 'I know I can't do everything, but I can do something.'" Visit the link in our bio to watch her moving TED Talk about how to advocate for love and acceptance when both seem in short supply.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 10, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text:
The world's reefs are losing coral faster than ever before, and yes, we humans are to blame. 🥺  But the good news is: When we can give coral a chance, it's actually resilient — and it can thrive. Coral scientist and @TEDFellow Kristen Marhaver PhD saw this firsthand when she went diving near the north shore of Curaçao. There, she saw 1,000-year-old corals lined up one after the other, corals that had lived through European colonialism and were now contending with climate change. She says she cried under water. In her TED Talk, Marhaver shares how these magnificent organisms reproduce and the methods she's developed to help them survive their fragile, early days of life. While many reefs have been damaged by warming waters and ocean acidification, they *can* bounce back — but they need some help from us. “An individual coral can go through tremendous trauma and fully recover if it's given a chance and it's given protection." says Marhaver. "Corals have always been playing the long game, and now so are we." Visit the link in our bio to see some more amazing coral like this and learn about her work.⁠
⁠
[Photo: courtesy Kristen Marhaver]

node.text: Sadly, too many students today don't realize that they're genuinely creative and talented. And it's because too many schools don't value — and sometimes actively  discourage! — the very things they're good at. In one of his TED Talks, the late Sir Ken Robinson explains how traditional education is actually preventing kids from developing and showcasing their natural abilities — and that we must allow them to experiment, take chances and occasionally fail. "If you're not prepared to be wrong," he says, "you'll never come up with anything original." Watch the full version to see why it's the most-viewed TED Talk ever: http://t.ted.com/2orrPtm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 06, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "Leadership is the responsibility to see those around us rise. It's not about beingin charge. about taking careofthosein our charge." SIMON SINEK LEADERSHIP EXPERT TED'.

node.text: You can be a leader no matter what your title says, says leadership expert @SimonSinek. "I know many people who sit at the highest levels of organizations who are not leaders," he says. "We do as they tell us because they have authority over us, but we don't trust them and we wouldn't follow them." In an exclusive discussion for TED Members with Head of TED Chris Anderson, Simon reflects on what it really takes to be a great leader, how you can nurture your personal relationships, and a simple (and fun!) game to help you identify your true purpose. Visit the link in our bio to watch! #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'WE HUMANS IDEAS.TED.COM Charcoal may be great for barbecues bad for the planet but it's TED'.

node.text:
Warning: We've got some bad news about your barbecue. 😬 While charcoal may be used in cooking all over the world for its affordability and flavor — when it comes to CO2 emissions and environmental destruction, it's one of the worst offenders. The fuel is traditionally produced by cutting down trees and burning them in kilns — a process that decimates forests and releases huge amounts of carbon pollution into the atmosphere. As you can imagine, that’s not too great for the 🌎. But before you cancel your backyard cookout, we want you to know there’s some good news: There are greener alternatives to charcoal. (Phew!). Visit the link in our bio to learn more about how to make your next outdoor barbecue more climate-friendly.⁠
⁠
[Image Credit: Stocksy]

node.text: Ever wonder why your voice always sounds so terrible — or just, unrecognizable — on recordings? There's actually a scientific reason way you *think* you sound is so different from how you actually sound. In her TED Talk, voice expert Rébecca Kleinberger explains the infuriating phenomenon: "Your outward voice travels through the air while your inward voice travels through your bones," she says. "Because of this, your inward voice is going to sound in a lower register and also more musically harmonical than your outward voice." Watch her fascinating full talk on the science of your many voices — and how you hear them — here: http://t.ted.com/QZb58m6

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on September 01, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
When Bjarke Ingels (@bjarkeingels) was asked by LEGO to create the "Home of the Brick," a museum in the company's home country of Denmark, he wanted to create a space that was as interactive and fun as the toy. In fact, he says it might be the only museum in the world where visitors can touch all the artifacts! With interconnected playgrounds on the roof and a square on the ground floor that's open to the public, it fits the bill. It's one of the many examples of futuristic and cutting-edge architecture from his TED Talk. "The Danish word for design is 'formgivning,' which literally means to give form to that which has not yet been given form," he says. "In other words, to give form to the future." Watch his full talk at the link in our bio to see more of these futuristic forms — including entire floating cities! — and learn about how they can help us adapt to a future with climate change. ⁠
⁠
[Image: courtesy Bjarke Ingels]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'IDEAS.TED.COM WE HUMANS We all know people who just can't apologize well, here's why ኣ W TED'.

node.text: Know someone who just won’t say sorry, even when they know they’re wrong? Turns out, there’s a psychological reason why! And it’s not just that they’re stubborn, says psychologist @GuyWinch. "People who cannot apologize often have such deep feelings of low self-worth that their fragile egos cannot absorb the blow of admitting they were wrong," he explains. Visit the link in our bio to learn about healthy ways to handle the non-apologizers in your life — and why, when it comes to fighting with them, you'll never win.

node.text: Feel like you’re going a million miles a minute most days? Us too! As technology keeps our world moving faster and faster, there is so much value in slowing down, says writer @Jacqueline_Woodson. That’s why she recommends you make time to “savor” your books. Reading this way can help you dive deep into the many layers of a story, honor the author’s work and truly understand each book’s lasting power. "We read to get lost, to forget the hard times we're living in," she says. "And we read to remember those who came before us, who lived through something harder." Watch her full talk on the power of reading slowly here: http://t.ted.com/7S8xv4m

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 25, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'TED Climate change is not the problem. Climate change is the most horrible symptom of an economic system that has been built for a few to extract every precious value out of this planet and its people.'.

node.text: A crisis of global climate migration is coming … and we’re not ready! Climate change is already affecting communities all over the world, including yours. In fact, scientists predict that climate change will displace more than 180 million people by 2100. In her TED Talk, disaster recovery lawyer Colette Pichon Battle walks through the economic and social systems responsible for this wave of migration — and the climate crisis in general — and what can be done to dismantle them. “Let's choose to make this next phase of our planetary existence beautiful,” she says, “And while we're at it, let's make it just and fair for everyone.” Visit the link in our bio to watch her full talk on how we can build resilient communities in the face of increasingly extreme weather — and why climate justice needs to be an integral part of the fight to slow climate change.
